page.title: 08Lavenham First School
page.content: Lavenham has a primary school built in 1896. The building originally housed 3 separate schools catering for children of all ages who lived in the village.It replaced the school which was held in the Church Rooms and it augmented the British National School on the Market Place.This building has since been demolished but the present school benefits from a residual trust.During the late 1950s children of secondary school age were removed to Stoke by Nayland. Educational provision in Suffolk was reorganised in 1972.Now the village school has a roll of about 100 children,aged 5 to 9, from Lavenham and surrounding villages. At 9 most chilren transfer to Stoke By Nayland Middle School,where they remain until they move to Great Cornard Upper School,Sudbury at the age of 13.
